article.description:
Dahntay Jones scored 19 points and Daniel
Ewing added 18 as No. 8 Duke beat North Carolina State 79-68 on
Saturday.
article.headline: Jones, Ewing help Duke win 27th straight home game
article.linkText: Duke breaks out early in defeat of N.C. State
article.story: DURHAM, N.C. (AP) -- The signs in the locker room spell out Duke's aggressive, contest-everything philosophy of defense. The eighth-ranked Blue Devils applied those rules well enough to beat North Carolina State on Saturday. Dahntay Jones scored 19 points and Daniel Ewing added 18 in Duke's 79-68 victory over the Wolfpack. Chris Duhon had 12 points for the Blue Devils (19-4, 9-4 Atlantic Coast Conference), who won their 27th straight game at Cameron Indoor Stadium. The win allowed Duke to remain tied for third in the league with No. 13 Maryland, which beat North Carolina 96-56 on Saturday. Behind a defense that pressured the Wolfpack's ballhandlers and got hands in passing lanes, the Blue Devils converted 24 turnovers into 31 points. That more than made up for the Wolfpack's 57 percent shooting, which included a 17-for-25 effort in the second half. "We felt that they're a team that no one has really pressured to the point where they're not able to run their offense,'' said Duhon, who had two of Duke's 13 steals. "We just wanted to speed them up a little bit, get in passing lanes to where they couldn't make sure passes and try to create offense from our defense.'' The 24 turnovers were a season-high for N.C. State, three more than the previous mark set in a loss to Maryland on Jan. 30. "Clearly the turnovers were our demise,'' Wolfpack coach Herb Sendek said. Julius Hodge had 18 points and Clifford Crawford added 17 for N.C. State (14-9, 7-5), which is fourth in the ACC. The loss dropped the Wolfpack to 1-8 on the road this season. N.C. State had beaten the Blue Devils 80-71 at the RBC Center on Jan. 22, ending a 13-game losing streak in the series. But Duke avoided any chance of a repeat Saturday, forcing 16 first-half turnovers and taking a double-digit lead early to beat the Wolfpack at Cameron for the eighth straight time. "Their pressure affected us tremendously,'' Crawford said. "In the first half, we really didn't play well or up to our potential. And that really put us in a deep, deep hole.'' The Blue Devils shot 47 percent, but again struggled from 3-point range. Duke came into the game shooting 29 percent from behind the arc in February, and was just 3-of-12 Saturday. Coach Mike Krzyzewski said the Blue Devils emphasized getting into the passing lanes during practices since Wednesday's 75-70 win over Maryland. He said the goal was both to create easy baskets and contain the Wolfpack's 3-point shooters. N.C. State, which came into the game averaging eight 3s per game, went 1-for-10 from behind the arc. "Although they shot a good percentage, it was 2-point baskets,'' Krzyzewski said. "That's OK.'' The Blue Devils went ahead to stay during a 12-0 run in the first half after an early technical foul on Hodge, taking a 44-27 halftime lead. The Wolfpack cut the lead to single digits three times in the second half, but Duke answered each time. The Wolfpack opened the second half with nine straight points to pull within eight. Hodge scored five in the spurt, which ended with Crawford's driving layup with 17:54 left. Duke answered with a 10-2 run -- six points coming from Ewing -- to take a 54-38 lead with 15 minutes left. The Blue Devils struggled to land the knockout blow, but had no trouble countering the Wolfpack's runs. N.C. State pulled within 63-55 on a putback by Josh Powell with about 6½ minutes left, but J.J. Redick nailed a 3 from the right corner on the next possession. Hodge then hit two free throws to cut the margin to nine, only to see Ewing knife through the lane for a layup and a 68-57 lead with 5:29 left. The Wolfpack got no closer than 10 points the rest of the way. "That just shows we are growing as a team and can deal with adversity,'' said Redick, who finished with 10 points. "A month ago, I don't know if we would've made that run in response like we did today.'' N.C. State led 9-8 early before Hodge was whistled for a technical foul with 14:05 left in the first half. Hodge threw an elbow at Jones after Jones had fouled him near midcourt and the players became tangled. Duke answered with 12 straight points, the last two coming on a fast break slam by Jones off a turnover, for a 20-9 lead with 11:04 left.
